title: DLL Hijacking Vulnerability in GlassWireSetup.exe

activities.message: Thank you. We are on it.
activities.markdown_message: Thank you. We are on it.

activities.message: We tried to release an update today but ran into an unexpected problem introduced by the NSIS update.  We hope to put the update out tomorrow so you can test and confirm it's fixed.  Thanks again for your report.
activities.markdown_message: We tried to release an update today but ran into an unexpected problem introduced by the NSIS update. We hope to put the update out tomorrow so you can test and confirm it's fixed. Thanks again for your report.

activities.message:
Thanks! If you can share any details about the NSIS update (especially if you believe it will apply to others) that would be great. As I'm chasing down folks and asking them to upgrade, I want to help ensure that whatever problem you hit they don't hit too.

Thanks again.

activities.message: I think the problem we found probably only applies to us.  The update breaks our installer with Windows 7 only for some reason but everything else seems to be OK.
activities.markdown_message: I think the problem we found probably only applies to us. The update breaks our installer with Windows 7 only for some reason but everything else seems to be OK.

activities.message:
Hello,

This update includes the NSIS vulnerability fix and GlassWire firewall exception fix.

To test please follow the instructions below.

1.       Download the installer https://www.dropbox.com/s/8f0f7q4b567hyu9/glasswire-setup-1.1.37.exe?dl=0

2.       Download this dll and copy it to the installer’s folder https://www.dropbox.com/s/5kzygrmqzu0rk3a/shfolder.dll?dl=0

3.       Start the installation.

4.       If the vulnerability is not fixed you’ll see a "Vulnerable to DLL Hijacking" message.

5.       Complete the installation;

6.       Uninstall GlassWire while the application is running. The application should be terminated on uninstallation;

7.       Please repeat these actions on a Virtual Machine too if you have one.

Please confirm the bug is fixed and we will release an update shortly.

Thank you for your help.
activities.markdown_message:
Hello,

This update includes the NSIS vulnerability fix and GlassWire firewall exception fix.

To test please follow the instructions below.

  1.   Download the installer https://www.dropbox.com/s/8f0f7q4b567hyu9/glasswire-setup-1.1.37.exe?dl=0

  2.   Download this dll and copy it to the installer’s folder https://www.dropbox.com/s/5kzygrmqzu0rk3a/shfolder.dll?dl=0

  3.   Start the installation.

  4.   If the vulnerability is not fixed you’ll see a "Vulnerable to DLL Hijacking" message.

  5.   Complete the installation;

  6.   Uninstall GlassWire while the application is running. The application should be terminated on uninstallation;

  7.   Please repeat these actions on a Virtual Machine too if you have one.

Please confirm the bug is fixed and we will release an update shortly.

Thank you for your help.

activities.message: Looks pretty good to me in Windows 8.1. I watched in Process Monitor and the only DLL that even attempted to load from the \Downloads\ folder was VERSION.dll. If replaced, the process would crash but I couldn't get code in its DLLMain to execute. I don't understand enough about what's special in "Version.dll" that leads to this behavior, but I see it in most of the executables I've tried.
activities.markdown_message: Looks pretty good to me in Windows 8.1. I watched in Process Monitor and the only DLL that even attempted to load from the \Downloads\ folder was VERSION.dll. If replaced, the process would crash but I couldn't get code in its DLLMain to execute. I don't understand enough about what's special in "Version.dll" that leads to this behavior, but I see it in most of the executables I've tried.

activities.message: Thank you for testing.  We hope to release an update tomorrow.  Once the update is live and you confirm it's fixed I'll set the award.
activities.markdown_message: Thank you for testing. We hope to release an update tomorrow. Once the update is live and you confirm it's fixed I'll set the award.

activities.message: The update is now live at our website.  Please confirm the problem is solved so I can finalize everything.  Happy Holidays.
activities.markdown_message: The update is now live at our website. Please confirm the problem is solved so I can finalize everything. Happy Holidays.

activities.message: Now we are seeing false positives with Avast and we're working to solve it.  We may have to remove the update if we're unable to solve it today.
activities.markdown_message: Now we are seeing false positives with Avast and we're working to solve it. We may have to remove the update if we're unable to solve it today.

activities.message: We are going to have to remove the update due to false positives from Avast that block GlassWire from being installed by all Avast users.  It appears Avast has the most market share of any antivirus.  This problem appears to be something Avast is detecting in NSIS itself so we cannot do anything about it.  I am trying to get Avast to white list GlassWire so we can do a relaunch but it's unlikely they will respond over the holidays.
activities.markdown_message: We are going to have to remove the update due to false positives from Avast that block GlassWire from being installed by all Avast users. It appears Avast has the most market share of any antivirus. This problem appears to be something Avast is detecting in NSIS itself so we cannot do anything about it. I am trying to get Avast to white list GlassWire so we can do a relaunch but it's unlikely they will respond over the holidays.

activities.message: Update removed due to Avast false positive and users claiming GlassWire is infected.  Trying to work with Avast to get the false positive fixed.
activities.markdown_message: Update removed due to Avast false positive and users claiming GlassWire is infected. Trying to work with Avast to get the false positive fixed.

activities.message:
Ugh, sorry to hear that.

How did you conclude that it's detecting NSIS itself? Slickrun (https://bayden.com/dl/sr-setup64.exe )  is built with NSIS2.49 and it comes back clean: https://www.virustotal.com/en/file/1595f87b9215bda7ed9c53fe270d9b1129d8c18fd5772426bd3fb2b3e68eab39/analysis/1450977532/

NSIS's own installer is built with NSIS 2.49 and comes back clean as well: https://www.virustotal.com/en/file/3c3a6fdf5de78e5e8adf08df43a053a8cd7c3480f9b887ffa079a7e0de75c7fa/analysis/1450977730/
activities.markdown_message:
Ugh, sorry to hear that.

How did you conclude that it's detecting NSIS itself? Slickrun (https://bayden.com/dl/sr-setup64.exe ) is built with NSIS2.49 and it comes back clean: https://www.virustotal.com/en/file/1595f87b9215bda7ed9c53fe270d9b1129d8c18fd5772426bd3fb2b3e68eab39/analysis/1450977532/

NSIS's own installer is built with NSIS 2.49 and comes back clean as well: https://www.virustotal.com/en/file/3c3a6fdf5de78e5e8adf08df43a053a8cd7c3480f9b887ffa079a7e0de75c7fa/analysis/1450977730/

activities.message: We built an empty uninstall.exe. It does absolutely nothing, it does not install or delete anything, it does not contain any files but we still see the same false positive.  If you have an idea of something else we can try please let me know and we will try it. NSIS generates the uninstaller.  Thank you.
activities.markdown_message: We built an empty uninstall.exe. It does absolutely nothing, it does not install or delete anything, it does not contain any files but we still see the same false positive. If you have an idea of something else we can try please let me know and we will try it. NSIS generates the uninstaller. Thank you.

activities.message: The update is released at GlassWire.com.  Please confirm the problem is solved.  Thank you.
activities.markdown_message: The update is released at GlassWire.com. Please confirm the problem is solved. Thank you.

activities.message:
I've confirmed that the original problem has been fixed. 

Unfortunately, it appears that GlasswireSetup.exe still uses an unqualified path when running CertUtil.exe and as a consequence a trojaned CertUtil.exe will execute from the \Downloads\ folder. Interestingly, it executes without any security warning that Windows would normally show for a downloaded executable run from the shell (suggesting that CreateProcess was used rather than ShellExecute).

To fix this, it might make the most sense to set the current working directory to the System folder early in the Setup process.

If you'd prefer that I open a new bug for this variant, please let me know!

I'm also curious why Glasswire is even manipulating the user's Trusted Publishers store at all?
activities.markdown_message:
I've confirmed that the original problem has been fixed.

Unfortunately, it appears that GlasswireSetup.exe still uses an unqualified path when running CertUtil.exe and as a consequence a trojaned CertUtil.exe will execute from the \Downloads\ folder. Interestingly, it executes without any security warning that Windows would normally show for a downloaded executable run from the shell (suggesting that CreateProcess was used rather than ShellExecute).

To fix this, it might make the most sense to set the current working directory to the System folder early in the Setup process.

If you'd prefer that I open a new bug for this variant, please let me know!

I'm also curious why Glasswire is even manipulating the user's Trusted Publishers store at all?

activities.message: Thank you for confirming the original problem is fixed.  Please open up a new bug for this new variant you found and we will begin working on it.  Please confirm I can close out this bug and I will do so.
activities.markdown_message: Thank you for confirming the original problem is fixed. Please open up a new bug for this new variant you found and we will begin working on it. Please confirm I can close out this bug and I will do so.

activities.message: Sure thing. Please close this as fixed.
activities.markdown_message: Sure thing. Please close this as fixed.

activities.message: Thanks for all your help!  I'll pay the bounty after January 7th, because when a bounty appears on HackerOne it attracts a lot of attention and we will get a massive influx of bug reports when some of our team is currently unavailable.  I am putting it on my calendar right now.
activities.markdown_message: Thanks for all your help! I'll pay the bounty after January 7th, because when a bounty appears on HackerOne it attracts a lot of attention and we will get a massive influx of bug reports when some of our team is currently unavailable. I am putting it on my calendar right now.

vulnerability_information_html:
GlasswireSetup.exe is subject to the attack described here: http://textslashplain.com/2015/12/18/dll-hijacking-just-wont-die/

You can get a simple demo with this harmless DLL:
https://bayden.com/dl/shfolder.dll

See attached image for proof of execution.
